ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: #2 I felt the QCI assigned homework was a REAL waste of time. I don't believe we were even evaluated. This assignment felt like unnecessary busy work. I really enjoyed the other assignments as these honed our professional writing skills and forced students to pay attention to the details.#5 I know we were rained out...but the more harvest trips, the better! The more interaction we have with practicioners, the more valuable the course.
Managing a forest must take in to account the machines that will be used and the landowner objectives that are to be met; this class helps you understand that.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: the field trips and learning from mike - it is awesome to work with practitioners
The best aspect: Learning from someone who practices forestry for a living!

The professor is not only a great teacher, but does an excellent job of interacting with students in order to best serve them. He also brings an incredible wealth of field experience and on the ground knowledge to the course.
The Southern Forestry Field Trip!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: coordinating field trips with silviculture - other than that awesome
The weather...I would have liked more field trips to see additional harvest operations.
I think this class is excellent.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Absolutely essential.
This course is critical to my overall program. It is the only course that effectively teaches the operations of forest management - an essential component to any MF degree.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: required and interested!
The course was well-recommended and I wanted to have a better understanding of forestry operations in the Northeast.
See above answer.
Because I felt like it was critical to fully understand forest management.
Interest.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes - especially the second half of the course!
Yes, with one exception. The course lacked in the quantitative aspect of forest operations. Inventory analysis was glossed over.
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: go for it! and DEFINITELY go on the southern forestry field tour. best thing i have done at yale.
This is an excellent course for someone who has no experience in operations. It is an enjoyable class for everyone.
You will not regret taking this class no matter what, but I highly recommend taking it and attending the Southern Forest Field Trip, my favorite experience at FES thus far!
Take this if you are interested in harvesting forests.
